Putting the piece in the kiln at 1075F for different rates of time will strike variations in the color depending on thickness of color application and layering of color throughout the working process. A light yellow transparent will darken to a pinkish orange with subtle reds.If you return any part of the piece to a molten state it will restart the striking process. I like to use this color without encasement. No need to reduce in the flame or work in an oxidizing atmosphere." - Mike Shelbo

name: Terps
manufacturer_description: Terps is the first cadmium based CFL color shifter. This Next-Gen cad is highly workable and will shift from Orange to Yellow, depending on the light source. Working Tip: Pre-heat in outer flame. Avoid rapid heating.

name: Tiger's Eye
manufacturer_description: Tiger's Eye is a Beryl based sparkle color utilizing the next generation sparkle technology found in Paparazzi. Working Tip: This color likes to be worked cool, but make sure you have your heat base built up while tooling or manipulating the glass to avoid developing a gray haze. Artist Description by Mike Shelbo: “I have been waiting for this sparkle for a long time. It really completes the sparkle palette for earth tones. Tiger’s Eye has such large sparkle flakes that when you catch it in different light it seems as though you see every color of the rainbow reflecting like a prism. At the same time, you can also see gold and silver flakes. The base color helps a lot with this effect. Similar to Beryl but a bit more vibrant, this transparent color works quite the same. It handles every type of working situation, although you want to avoid long exposure to a heavy propane flame. It can be worked solid or blown, thick or thin. I prefer dense layers of Tiger’s Eye so you can really see the range of spectrum within the sparkle.” – Mike Shelbo

name: Tonic
manufacturer_description: Tonic has a vintage glass look and is a younger sibling of Rain Drop. For best results, this crisp, high index color should be used in a neutral flame. Working Tip: Work neutral to oxidizing for best results. A reducing flame will cause red streaking. Artist Description by Mike Shelbo: "Tonic is a transparent blue, the color of an aquamarine gem. The color becomes more vibrant and its higher refractive index shows when used with itself in applications that allow the Tonic layer to be as thick as possible. When used as tubing, applied on clear or as coiled color, if the Tonic will be exposed to a lot of different working flames and long times in and out of the kiln, I advise a thin clear coat to protect the surface from overworking. Too much propane in your flame can result in a copper reduction leaving you with red streaks or patches on the surface of the un-encased Tonic. Too much over oxidizing can leave you with a surface haze or scuzz that must be swiped to remove. I often recommend a thin layer of clear frit over Tonic or evenly coated clear rod over your entire prep. I have used Tonic without encasement many times on solid sculpture and had good results, but I have seen a warming or flashing flame haze up a section. Working Tonic in as close to a neutral flame and away from the face of your torch is wise and will get you the best results with the color. If you have worked Raindrop in the past, this color is very similar in working properties. My favorite application is to gather up rods into 18mm or thicker sections and sculpt them into figurines. This next generation transparent is definitely a must have to fill out the rainbow palette. It can be layered over other colors like white for a nice pastel, but will be a faint tint unless applied as a 5-7mm thick layer. The first impression Tonic made on me was the thought that it was the color of window glass or old soda bottles, both aqua blue colors that I have always been fond of.” – Mike Shelbo

name: Tree Hugger
manufacturer_description: Tree Hugger, 4497 is darker than Shamrock and is a bold dark green. Like Shamrock, Tree Hugger is smooth, creamy and easy to work. Working Tip: Work this color in a neutral flame. Garage at 975° F, Anneal at 1050° F. Artist Description by Mike Shelbo"This opaque green is a shade darker than GA Shamrock and is equally as dense in saturation of the color. It can be drawn down to a very thin stringer and still hold its true color. It works very smooth for being such a dark green, which are often prone to stiffness. It melts easily and has no visible termination points when separated from itself. While I have had success with encasement under a thick layer of clear, I still suggest testing and experimentation when using opaque greens to check if the application works in different circumstances. GA Tree Hugger adds to the already existing ROYGBIV color fade of opaques available from GA and is becoming more and more one of my favorite colors to sculpt with. I like to pair it with GA Agua Mist.

name: Triple Passion
manufacturer_description: Triple Passion, 786 was introduced as an easy striking amber to purple color. Due to its formulation this color quickly, easily and consistently strikes through a wide range of bright and delightful purples. The use of color-changing borosilicate exploded soon after Glass Alchemy introduced this color to the market. This is a must have in every glass studio! Working Tip: Get this color white hot to erase the striking history. A variety of effects are achievable depending on how long you flame/kiln strike. Artist Description by Mike Shelbo: "You know it, you love it, and you can use it so many ways! Triple Passion is a striking color full of silver goodness. This means that as your translucent base glass shifts from a golden yellow to amber and into purples and violets you will also see a reaction from the silver adding in blue and green and purple hues. To best understand how this will work as you make your piece, heat your color rod to a molten state, let it cool, then with a normal working flame heat for a second at a time and pause in between to watch results. The striking happens quickly and that is why short exposure increments will yield large differences. Encase with clear to trap luster and pearlescent qualities. Color layer thickness will determine final color and ability to control finishing effects." - Mike Shelbo

name: Turquoise
manufacturer_description: Turquoise, 445 was inspired by Southwest American Indian art. To mimic natural turquoise we wanted a color that would develop organic red highlights within the green coloration like the stone. Working Tip: Work this color in a neutral flame. Garage at 975° F, Anneal at 1050° F. Use of reduction at the end of the project can produce subtle red tones. Artist Description by Mike Shelbo: "This color is a natural earth-toned opaque greenish blue. Turquoise is great for solid sculpture and blown work. The density of the color will stay true to the color of the rod before manipulation but when blown, it can become a milky translucent and opalescent version of itself. This is best achieved by sandwiching between clear and blowing thin. Turquoise works creamy but the slightest bit stiffer than other opaques. Overworking the surface of the color when not encased in clear can lead to undesired surface texture and finish. However, when desired you can use a reduction flame with heavy propane on unencased Turquoise before you put your piece in the annealer to bring out the copper, which will result in very natural toned red tints and streaks interacting with your base color." - Mike Shelbo

name: Twilight
manufacturer_description: Twilight, 548 was designed as part of a series of 6 blues and greens to provide a range of hues and intensities that would work well with each other as well as set off the bright Crayon colors. Working Tip: Work this color in a neutral flame. Garage at 975° F, Anneal at 1050° F. Artist Description by Mike Shelbo: "Twilight is the slightest bit stiffer than Glass Alchemy Peacock and Agua Azul but works just the same, nice and creamy. This blue is a deep, opaque color that is darker than Peacock, but still a very distinct blue that has a special place in the color palette. It works great for sculpting solid work and for blown work. Twilight lends well to many styles of application. I also like Twilight for murrine because of the density of the color and the ability to hold up well when drawn down to different sizes. Working this color properly is the same as working other opaques and Crayon colors. Twilight does not sublime or boil and can be intensely spot heated with a sharp flame for detail and welds. Small variations in darker tones emerge with intense spot heating when color is not encased." - Mike Shelbo

name: Ultramarine
manufacturer_description: Darker than Aquamarine, Ultramarine is a beautiful blue-green. It is a highly usable copper free color. If you like Atlantis, but are looking for a cheaper option, this is your color. There is no chance of REDuction with this one! Working Tip: This is a user friendly color and can withstand long working times. As always, we suggest you use a neutral flame.

name: Unicorn Tears
manufacturer_description: Unicorn Tears is a beautiful pink-purple with a touch of silver for a fumey effect. Working Tip: Work in a neutral flame and use a slightly reducing flame to bring the silver effects to the surface. You can also try running this color through multiple kiln cycles to activate the silver. Note: Thomas' Test Lab contains good quality glass. The color formulation is still not final and final QC parameters have not been set.

name: Walnut
manufacturer_description: Walnut, 8475 was a later release. We were receiving many requests to create a color that matched the saturation of Cobalt-5, 515 in a brown tone. Recognizing that this was an important color, we did several months of development work and were very pleased to introduce Black Walnut, 8475. A deep rich opaque brown, this color works well in many applications and has become an important part of our lineup. Working Tip: Work in neutral flame to avoid reduction (gray wisps). Artist Description by Mike Shelbo: "This color is a saturated what you see is what you get opaque deep brown. It works very nicely in all flame atmospheres and in both blown and solid work. It melts into itself easily and is great for detail applied by stringers and in larger applications. Walnut seems opaque but when blown thin or applied in very thin stringers it will show its translucent quality. It can be worked for long periods of time without encasement and with heavy manipulation. This is one of the staple colors in the earth toned palette Glass Alchemy has to offer." - Mike Shelbo

name: Wood Glue
manufacturer_description: ﻿This pastel based color is back by popular demand!! Wood Glue is a sibling of Glue Stick, with a little extra something to give it a great neutral color. Working Tip: Be sure not to get this color too hot when in a thin application as to not cook out the pastel base and turn it transparent. Blow outs work best of the pastel colors. Note: Thomas' Test Lab contains good quality glass. The color formulation is still not final and final QC parameters have not been set.

name: Yellow Crayon
manufacturer_description: Yellow Crayon is a dense, bright cadmium based school bus yellow. It is great for all applications and will remain dense when pulled down thin. Try Acid Yellow Crayon if you are looking for a little more kick in your color. Working Tip: Pre-heat in outer flame. Avoid rapid heating. Artist Description by Mike Shelbo: "This color is a true yellow opaque. It's very natural and has an earthy tone to it. Not too dark, not too bright, Yellow Crayon is just right. Works like other crayon colors and prefers to be in the mid to outer region of the flame but can come close to the torch tip in quick passes and light repeated spot heats. The color density holds well in stringers, canework, and murrine. Blowing with Yellow Crayon works well with encasement or color on the surface of your piece and will stay dense until the color layer is blown thinner than 1mm. Compliments and contrasts with almost the entire Glass Alchemy palette, try Yellow Crayon, 304 and Tiger's Eye, 8595 for bumblebees or with Shamrock, 4494 for a classic combo." - Mike Shelbo

name: Zen
manufacturer_description: Zen is a beautiful soft aqua blue-green that adds a tranquil touch to the pastel line-up. Zen is a pastel version of Tonic, and does contain copper. For a copper free version, try Nimbus. Working Tip: Work neutral to oxidizing for best results. A reducing flame will cause REDuction. While this color can be worked without encasement, for longer working times, we recommend a thin sleeve of clear. Be sure not to get this color too hot when in a thin application as to not cook out the pastel base and turn it transparent. Blow outs work best of the pastel colors.

name: Acadian Night (Dense Silver)
manufacturer_description: Acadian Night is a dense sparkle color with a blue hue and silver striking effect.

name: Acadian Night
manufacturer_description: Our newest batch of Acadian Night is a sparkle color with a blue hue and silver striking effect.

name: Autumn Sample Packs
manufacturer_description: The seasons are changing and we have a sample pack to match. These are a mix of B/B+ quality, weigh 1lb 1oz and come with two rods of each color. Dense Pineapple Juice, Mango, Exp. Green Olive, Russet, Transitional Cinnabar, and Moist Raspberry.

name: Blue Cheese
manufacturer_description: A true staple of the Greasy collection, Blue Cheese is a Creamy opaque blue that really pops.

name: Blue Satin
manufacturer_description: One of our classic colors. A royal blue color with a satin sheen.

name: Chocolate Opal (Dense)
manufacturer_description: A dense version of our Chocolate Opal, this color looks purple or brown in different lights.

name: Chocolate Opal
manufacturer_description: Chocolate Opal features many vibrant hues that shift in different light spectrums, from deep purple to brilliant brown.

name: Creme Brulee
manufacturer_description: A Creamy color that can be used in multiple applications.

name: Dark Wildberry Satin
manufacturer_description: Darker variety of Wildberry with satin chatoyancy. This shade is nice and dark when solid, and can be sleeved or thinned for a more transparent or translucent finish.

name: Dense Glopal
manufacturer_description: This is a odd batch of dense Glopal rod with a slight satin.

name: Dense Orange Opal (Unique)
manufacturer_description: This is a dense opal orange color with slight satin. Best worked in a gentle flame or encased.

name: Dense Pineapple Juice
manufacturer_description: This is a lovely dense cadmium yellow based color.

name: Dense Rose Quartz
manufacturer_description: Dense Rose Quartz is a dense version Rose Quartz with extra milky opal effect. Under CFL it goes to a more intense electric hot pink.

name: Diet Blue Cheese (Variant)
manufacturer_description: This is a variant of our diet blue cheese. A lighter version of our classic blue cheese.

name: Euro
manufacturer_description: A clear that glows blue under UV.

name: Exp. Black Pearl
manufacturer_description: Experience the beauty of the Exp. Black Pearl Rod - a stunning, rod with an opalescent finish and a satin feel. Slowly pre heat rod and work it gently.

name: Exp. Black
manufacturer_description: Greasy Glass black rod. Our black consists of a super dense Wildberry variable. When thinned or exposed to bright backlight the color can show blue/purple. Keep dense for the most black affect.

name: Exp. Blood Orange
manufacturer_description: Vibrant transparent orange. There are some subtle variations in the strike from yellow to red and orange.

name: Exp. Blood Red
manufacturer_description: Bright yet deep toned transparent red rod that really pops.

name: Exp. Blood Red (unique)
manufacturer_description: Bright yet deep transparent red rod that really pops. This unique batch varies slightly in tone from the original, almost in the direction of a red orange though still definitely in the Blood Red family.

name: Exp. Blue Phoenix
manufacturer_description: A blue striking opal color that produces a range of hues from red to purple.

name: Exp. Blue
manufacturer_description: Light in shade transparent blue.

name: Exp. Blueberry Opal
manufacturer_description: This is a navy blue color in the same family as sonic.

name: Exp. Bronze Pearl
manufacturer_description: A Stunning experimental bronze colored extremely metallic looking color with opalescence to rival a pearl. Bronze Pearl shimmers and shines like a brilliant sparkle color, and also contains depth from the opal effect. This unique batch may have variations in color, and crystal size.

name: Exp. Cinnabar
manufacturer_description: A dense orange cadmium based color.

name: Exp. Coral
manufacturer_description: This is a cadmium based orange that looks similar to the marine invertebrates at the bottom of the sea.

name: Exp. Coraline Satin
manufacturer_description: Coraline Satin is a cadmium red satin color worked best in a gentle flame or encased. This is a limited batch available while supplies last.

name: Exp. Cosmos
manufacturer_description: A silver striking black that produces a range of colors.

name: Exp. Dark Blue Raspberry
manufacturer_description: Intriguing dark striking rod combining a medium saturation cobalt blue and a strong transparent ruby that strikes in the flame as well as the kiln.

name: Exp. Dark Green Pearl
manufacturer_description: Similar to Bronze Pearl, this Experimental Dark Green version appears dark and mysterious.

name: Exp. Dense Coral (variant)
manufacturer_description: This is similar to our coral but a little bit more opaque. Best worked in a gentle flame or encased.

name: Exp. Dense Yellow Opal
manufacturer_description: This is a vivid yellow with opal qualities. Color works best in a neutral to oxidizing flame or encased.

name: Exp. Dense Yellow Opal (unique)
manufacturer_description: This Exp. Dense Yellow Opal Rod is an ideal choice for a one-of-a-kind piece. Its unique mustard color and dense opal structure provide a visually striking effect.

name: Exp. Desert Rose
manufacturer_description: This is a cadmium-based orange with pinkish blush tones. Works best in a gentle flame or encased.

name: Exp. Poofs (Dense)
manufacturer_description: A cadmium based orange works best in neutral flame.

name: Exp. Green Olive
manufacturer_description: This is an experimental green color, best worked gently in neutral to oxidizing flames or encased.

name: Exp. Green Opal (Dense)
manufacturer_description: This is a one of our new green opal colors, this is a dense batch.

name: Exp. Green Opal (unique)
manufacturer_description: A cadmium based green opal. This color works best in neutral to oxidizing flames or encased. This batch is slightly different than the original.

name: Exp. Green Opal
manufacturer_description: A cadmium based green opal. This color works best in neutral to oxidizing flames or encased.

name: Exp. Light Blue Crimson
manufacturer_description: Exp. Light Blue Crimson is a flame striking red with a light blue cobalt base.

name: Exp. Light Orange Rainbow
manufacturer_description: This color can produce a range of colors. Samples were struck in the kiln at 1125 for a short amount of time.

name: Exp. Orange
manufacturer_description: A vivid semi transparent cadmium based orange.

name: Exp. Pink Grapefruit
manufacturer_description: This is an experimental orange/pink cadmium color with similarities to orange opal.

name: Exp. Sonic Satin (Dense)
manufacturer_description: Our classic sonic with a satin twist.

name: Exp. Transparent Green
manufacturer_description: An experimental transparent green. Best worked in an oxidizing flame or encased.

name: Exp. Yellow Opal
manufacturer_description: Our newest batch of yellow opal rod. A vivid cadmium yellow with opal qualities best worked in a soft flame or encased.

name: Globalt
manufacturer_description: Global is a light cobalt color that glows a strong blue under UV light.

name: Glopal
manufacturer_description: Glopal is an easy to work and stable opal with a pink UV glow. Milky opaque appearance to unworked tube, with UV glow and opal quality allowing for more or less transparency depending on working conditions. Use a hotter flame for more transparent finish and less heat for a more opaque final product. A thin layer of clear adds durability for higher temp flames and sculpting.

name: Gold Purple
manufacturer_description: A gold based purple opal color. Color needs to be full worked for purple to strike. To avoid hazing on gold colors work in neutral to oxidizing flame or encase.

name: Grease Stain (Light Strike)
manufacturer_description: A yellowish color with light silver striking characteristics.

name: Grease Stain
manufacturer_description: A silver based striking color.

name: Green Energy (Light Strike)
manufacturer_description: This is a silver striking green, you can get a range of color from due to the striking properties.

name: Ice Water (UV)
manufacturer_description: This icy looking transparent glows pink under blacklight. A subtle hint of satin creates the ice water effect, resulting in a standalone clear transparent, or as a component in building layered colored tubes.

name: Icy Blue Satin
manufacturer_description: A icy blue with a satin shimmer and Uv reactive.

name: Jungle Juice (variant)
manufacturer_description: Jungle Juice is a rich dark green color with sparkle effect. Work gently and does not like deep encasements.

name: Light Bright
manufacturer_description: A clear that glows Pink/Orange under Uv light.

name: Light Olive Oil
manufacturer_description: A transparent yellow with slight opal affect.

name: Light Phoenix
manufacturer_description: Light Phoenix appears as a bright and rich ruby red. Very similar shade of red as standard Phoenix with a finished appearance closer to a traditional ruby red than an opal version. This is a perfect option when seeking a true transparent red that shines bright. Light Phoenix may appear transparent clear when working and before annealing. For a faster strike, raise kiln temperature as high as 1100.

name: Light Russet
manufacturer_description: A light brown with a slit tint of orange.

name: Mango
manufacturer_description: Mango is a vibrant translucent yellow orange in the pineapple juice family. Best worked in a gentle flame or encased.

name: Marina (Dense)
manufacturer_description: A denser batch than our classic Marina. Works best in neutral to oxidizing flames or encased.

name: Marina
manufacturer_description: Crisp aquatic blue reminiscent of a clear pond on a bright summer day, Marina is a copper based opal blue. Marina is similar to and in the family of Hydro. Like all opal type colors, it will appear more transparent when worked hotter and more milky when worked cooler. This new batch is slightly more transparent than the last batch.

name: Moist Raspberry (Unique)
manufacturer_description: This Moist Raspberry (Unique) Rod adds a vibrant pop of color to any project with its flame striking ruby red hue.

name: Moist Raspberry
manufacturer_description: A striking red, for best results flame strike then kiln strike.

name: Neo Opal (Dense)
manufacturer_description: A more dense version of our classic Neo Opal.

name: Neo Opal
manufacturer_description: Our classic Neo Opal Rod a translucent purple color with opal properties.

name: Opal Light
manufacturer_description: Opal Light is a lighter variety of Gopal with the same working characteristics. It has less opal strike which makes this a good color for overlay variations.

name: Peach Opal Agate
manufacturer_description: Lovely pinkish opal color that verges into an occasional amber.

name: Phoenix
manufacturer_description: Phoenix is juicy opal red color in the range of ruby with flashes of purple. Phoenix can produce a range of colors depending on strike.

name: Pineapple
manufacturer_description: Pineapple is a light yellow cadmium color worked best in a gentle neutral flame.

name: Pumpkin
manufacturer_description: A cadmium based color in similar shade to that of a pumpkin.

name: Purple Rainbow (unique)
manufacturer_description: A unique Striking purple rainbow. Wonderful silver based striking effect in this transparent purple. Work this color using flame chemistry in between neutral and oxidizing to maintain transparency. Strike using a slightly reducing flame or by leaving to soak in the kiln. Note that raising the temperature of the kiln is not always necessary for striking purple rainbow. 1080F for 3 - 4 hours

name: Rainbow Opal
manufacturer_description: The Rainbow Opal Rod adds a unique level of color and shimmer in the flame with its opalescent rainbow color shift. It works in both oxidizing and neutral atmospheres and contains a combination of opal and cfl to maximize color enhancement. Its striking effects add a vibrant decorative touch to any glass design.

name: Rainbow Sample Pack V12
manufacturer_description: These rainbow sample packs are darker/dense opal colors. They contain two rods of each color, Dark Phoenix, Russet Opal, Yellow Opal Satin, Green Opal, Blueberry Opal, and Dense Neo Opal.

name: Rainbow Sample Pack V13
manufacturer_description: These rainbow sample packs have 2 rods of each of the following colors Dark Phoenix, Exp. Orange, Dense Yellow Opal, Green Opal, Sonic, and Dense Neo Opal.

name: Rainbow Sample Pack V14
manufacturer_description: These rainbow sample packs are 1lb 2oz and have 2 rods of each color. Transitional Phoenix, Exp. Coral, Exp. Dense Yellow Opal, Green Opal, Marina, and Neo Opal.

name: Rainbow Sample Pack V15
manufacturer_description: We have another installation of our Rainbow Sample packs. This version is 1lb 1oz and includes two rods of each color - Transitional Phoenix, Dense Orange Opal (unique), Exp. Yellow Opal, Exp. Green Opal, Marina, and Neo Opal.

name: Rose Quartz (Transparent)
manufacturer_description: Transparent Rose Quartz is a lovely intense transparent pink with CFL reactivity. Under CFL it goes to a more intense electric hot pink.

name: Rose Quartz
manufacturer_description: Rose Quartz is a lovely transparent pink with slight opal effect. Under CFL it goes to a more intense pink.

name: Russet Opal
manufacturer_description: A light brown with opal qualities.

name: Russet
manufacturer_description: One of our newest browns added to the pallet. Works best in neutral flame.

name: Shifty Peach Light Opal Satin
manufacturer_description: Shifts from peach to pink under cfl, has a light opal and satin

name: Silver Opal
manufacturer_description: A silver based opal color.

name: Smog
manufacturer_description: A blue grey, with similarities to the hydro family with out the copper properties.

name: Sonic
manufacturer_description: Sonic is a rich blue opal. Similar in color to Dense Blue Cheese with an opal effect throughout.

name: Sparkle
manufacturer_description: Shiny metallic sparkle color. This is a great blingy sparkle rod in a classic gray metallic shade. Sparkle is a no-chrome metallic flake meaning it can be worked in any setting, surface or deep encasement.

name: Striking Sample Pack V1
manufacturer_description: This striking sample pack contains some of our striking colors. There are two rods of each color Light Moist Raspberry, Olive Oil Light, Grease Stain, Green Energy Light Strike, Transparent Gold Purple, and Cosmos.

name: Transitional Cinnabar
manufacturer_description: This is a semitransparent cadmium based orange, best worked in neutral to gentle oxidizing flames or encased.

name: Transitional Mango
manufacturer_description: Mango is a vibrant translucent yellow orange in the pineapple juice family. Best worked in a gentle flame or encased. This batch is more transparent then the last with a slight satin.

name: Transitional Phoenix
manufacturer_description: A red color with slight opal. This Phoenix is transitional due the amount of opal, it is in between Transparent Phoenix and Phoenix.

name: Transitional Rose Quartz
manufacturer_description: Rose Quartz is a lovely intense pink with CFL reactivity. Under CFL it goes to a more intense electric hot pink. Transitional refers to the opal content of the color and represents the mid point between Rose Quartz and Transparent Rose Quartz.

name: Transparent Coral
manufacturer_description: This is a cadmium based semi transparent orange.

name: Transparent Gold Purple
manufacturer_description: A transparent royal purple. The purple in this color is brought out by fully working it in cycles of letting it cool down and reheating similar to working an opal color.

name: Transparent Gold Purple (Unique)
manufacturer_description: A unique version of our transparent gold purple rod. This is unique due to the saturation of gold in the color and the hue before being melted. To bring out purple color must be fully worked.

name: Transparent Marina
manufacturer_description: A transparent non opal version of marina. This color works best in neutral to oxidizing flames, or encased.

name: Transparent Phoenix
manufacturer_description: Transparent Phoenix appears as a bright and rich ruby red. Very similar shade of red as standard Phoenix with a finished appearance closer to a traditional ruby red than an opal version. This is a perfect option when seeking a true transparent red that shines bright. Color can produce more of an opal effect when encased.

name: Transparent Shifty Peach Opal
manufacturer_description: A transparent version of our shifty peach. Changes from peach to bright pink under cfl light.

name: Transparent Shifty Sauce
manufacturer_description: A transparent color that shifts from yellow to pink under CFL.

name: Transparent Wildberry Satin (transitional)
manufacturer_description: Transparent version of Wildberry Satin.

name: Transparent Yellow Opal
manufacturer_description: A yellow with light opal, use neutral flame for best results.

name: White Satin
manufacturer_description: Hand pulled creamy opaque white with brilliant satin and pink under UV light. Satin colors really shine when encased.

name: Wildberry (variant)
manufacturer_description: This Wildberry variant has a slight satin effect, and stays opaque when worked. Best results in a neutral/oxidizing flame.

name: Wildberry Satin
manufacturer_description: Pleasing variety of Wildberry with a nice satin content. Mostly translucent color that will appear closer to opaque if kept thick, and more transparent if thinned or stretched.

name: Yoshi (Milky)
manufacturer_description: Milky Yoshi, a staple of the Greasy collection. Clean and nearly opaque with a strong CFL shift. This is B grade due to streaks.Easy to work. Preheat tubing slowly in kiln to avoid cracking.

name: Yoshi
manufacturer_description: Yoshi, a staple of the Greasy Glass collection. A vibrant green that shifts pink under CFL light.

name: Almond Nugget
manufacturer_description: A light almond colored glass that when encased and using an oxidizing flame has inside veils of ambers to wispy blues but become more opaque with a reducing flame. Un-encased colors are lighter amber. Pulls thin, stays creamy, and nice for deep encasements.

name: Cinnabar
manufacturer_description: A striking color that is a dark shade of ruby. It develops its permanent color while working and doesn’t overstrike.

name: Cherry Brandy
manufacturer_description: An earthy red opaque color that strikes to multiple red hues. This creamy color is easy to work, but needs a neutral flame.

name: American Beauty
manufacturer_description: Gina Gaffner - "American Beauty is a beautiful deep dark red that can be thinned out with clear and can go along way and is super workable in all flames. This red will get super dark the longer you garage it in the kiln".

name: Violet Hue
manufacturer_description: It's a fun color to work with, because so many effects are possible. Working it slowly in a neutral to reducing atmosphere gives you hazy purples and greens and milky colors. Working fast in a hot, oxidizing environment gives you corals and raspberry reds, with some purple highlights.

name: Carmen Red
manufacturer_description: Gina Gaffner - "Carmen Red when worked on a a super cold flame (high oxygen) this color comes out beautifully. Another nice trick that I find with most cad colors is preheating them in the kiln before working them in the flame. Once cad colors are nice a warm you can typically get away with a hotter flame to get nice detail work done".

name: Caribbean Coral
manufacturer_description: This color produces a wonderful array of color swirls varying from salmon, corals, lavenders and purples. Work this glass hot with an oxidizing flame and the metals come out to play. Flame striking produces bolder colors.

name: Charles Brown
manufacturer_description: Transparent brown. This easy to use color has a smooth consistency and is great for sculpture and color blow outs.

name: Encased Sunshine Yellow
manufacturer_description: It’s covered with clear glass and you can use it inside or out without any problem.

name: Lemon Yellow
manufacturer_description: Lovely yellow color, resist boiling. Beautiful with slight translucency to it and is brilliantly easy to work. If it does boil on you a bit, just let that area cool and then dip in and out of the flame a few times. It is good is to use it as a base to lay stripes over it.

name: Exotic Citrus Yellow
manufacturer_description: A lemon color with some amber colors coming through. Blows out nice and easy. Friendly, easy strikingh.

name: Yellow Pearl
manufacturer_description: Gina Gaffner - "Yellow Pearl is a perfect color to layer over another to create organic texture. I love layering it with colors to create the juicy insides of many of my fruit and veggie pieces. This color seems to get a little darker when garaged in the kiln for a long time".

name: Luminous Yellow
manufacturer_description: Luminous yellow is like the early morning light on the volcano slopes of Maui, crisp, clear and bright.

name: Orchard Plum
manufacturer_description: This new multi-color has delightful amber-rose to plum with swirls of blue and silver. Very smooth consistency and good in all applications.

name: Light Purple Haze
manufacturer_description: A light transparent yellow with a purple haze which can develop a light white and yellow mix. A reducing flame will give the surface a metallic sheen. This color seems light from within.

name: Exotic Citrus-Grapefruit
manufacturer_description: Gina Gaffner - "Exotic Grapefruit Citrus is so organic I am able to use it for many fruits and veggies. I currently use it for my grapefruit pieces and my beets. The color works great in all flame types. A high propane flame will bring out the grapefruit color the most".

name: Sunset Orange
manufacturer_description: Gina Gaffner - "Sunset Orange hangs strong with the rest of the cadmium colors Momka's has to offer. Stable and easy to work with no worry of boiling. It is super dense as well".

name: Challenge Gerber Orange
manufacturer_description: Challenge series color with vivid orange stripes is easy to use and versatile.

name: Challenge Gerber Pink
manufacturer_description: Challenge series color, can be cut into murrini and has versatile uses. Gerber Pink can be struck to achieve deeper color; stable in deep encasements.

name: Encased Carmen Red
manufacturer_description: It’s covered with clear glass and you can use it inside or out without any problem.

name: Challenge Gerber Red
manufacturer_description: Challenge series color. Works well in deep encasements, but use a soft flame to avoid boiling. Like all the challenge series colors, this can be used as murrini, twisties, coil pots and the rest.

name: Palitra Orange
manufacturer_description: Each rod from Sunset Orange is covered separately with clear glass. Works easy inside or out.

name: Challenge Sunflower
manufacturer_description: Challenge series yellow color, can be cut into murrini and has great versatility. Pull into various sized stringer, even very thin stringer will hold its color and make beautiful flowers. Sunflower is stable, but needs to be worked cool in deep encasement to avoid bubbling.

name: Greener Trails
manufacturer_description: This multi-color rod has tones of green and amber-yellow shades all separated by clear. Favorite of bead makers.

name: Brown Glitter
manufacturer_description: This rich sparkly brown is very saturated and works smooth. Use a slightly reduced flame or oxidizing to neutral - melts & flows smoothly. The reflection of the sparkle will pick up adjacent colors. Don’t overwork or deep encase.

name: Cobalt Blue
manufacturer_description: One of the most appealing basic colors, is easy to work with and is little stiffer than other transparent colors. Cobalt can take lots of heat. Avoid reducing flame. Neutral flame works best.

name: Blue Flambé
manufacturer_description: Bright and lively blue and plays, beautifully as a surface color in sculpture. Work in a neutral flame, not too oxidizing for this one. Part of the beauty is in the haze that develops, yielding sky blues and purples and bright, royal blues. Generally develops beautifully just as it is works.

name: Silky Satin Blue
manufacturer_description: A very stable semi transparent blue with a touch of green that works easily in all flames. When encased has a light silky sheen.

name: Alaska Night
manufacturer_description: Blue-black striking color that changes into black, blue, gray, dark purple and bright blue. It’s wonderful in all applications. A fun color to work with that can develop silver reflective with a metallic sheen. Try this encased with a reducing flame.

name: Rainbow Blue
manufacturer_description: A dark blue glass with violet overtones. Work in a neutral flame and finish with a light reduction.

name: Blue Lightning
manufacturer_description: A cobalt based color which contains silver. This color strikes to opal with greens, blues and whites.

name: Blue Treasure
manufacturer_description: This multi-color glass offers blues and yellows that combine to make a wonderful murrini for flowers, jellyfish caps and realistic eyes that work best with a contrasting color. A myriad of color effects when deep encased. Experiment with this one; twisties, stringer, ghostly effects are all great. A favorite for ring making.

name: Crystal Blue
manufacturer_description: This is a beautiful transparent blue. Very clear blue and easy to use color. No boiling issues. Use an oxidizing flame, as you can get some slight red reductions with this glass.

name: Forget-Me-Not
manufacturer_description: Challenge series color with blue stripes and subtle yellow centers make fantastic murrini, twisties and wraps.

name: Cloud
manufacturer_description: Silver, gray and yellow light tones come through a clear base. Like the sun shining through after it rains.

name: Blue Reflection
manufacturer_description: Striking color with a light green, blue and purple.

name: Violet Iris
manufacturer_description: Transparent purple/violet with a lot less silver than Silver Iris. This is a great color for thick applications, sculptural work, and blow-outs.

name: Magic Mirror
manufacturer_description: Swirling honey with wisps of blue-purple and silver reflection. Blown out it tends to be a nice amber honey color. Outside work, with an oxidizing flame, gives a slight mirroring and iridescence.

name: Brisk Light Green
manufacturer_description: Momka's newest color.

name: Guacamole
manufacturer_description: A nice saturated opaque green. Less yellow than Martini olive. Use a gentle neutral flame.

name: Ivy Green
manufacturer_description: This is a beautiful rich opaque green. A true green, and very friendly.

name: Martini Olive
manufacturer_description: It is the lighter of our two opaque greens. Care must be taken to prevent boiling. Use a neutral flame.

name: Silver Pine
manufacturer_description: This is a nice opaque green with silver in it. You can achieve some lovely blue and green transparent luster's.

name: Sparkly Green
manufacturer_description: Smooth light transparent color with a lot of sparkling green. Work middle to cool flame. Slight oxidizing works best. Strikes with light tones to blue and yellow.

name: Green Envy
manufacturer_description: A very rich transparent green that develops faint wispy blue under strong oxidizing flame. Neutral flame to surface color tends to opacify while interior color surfaces develop a range of colors from tan to blue. Careful not to reduce, it will give an opaque red to exposed surfaces.

name: Green Dragon 049
manufacturer_description: Extremely smooth semi-transparent olive green sparkling green color with pearl essence. Start with a cool flame and then this glass can take any flame well. Not appropriate with deep encasing.

name: Silver Beach
manufacturer_description: A fast striking purple that is great for all applications. Oxidizing and neutral flames will give you dark purples, amber, yellows and blues. Silver Beach has stable color in deep encasement. Experimentation can yield surprising colors in pink, peach and green.

name: Green Flambé
manufacturer_description: This is one of our newest colors and is a green, blue silver color that works well in any flame and reduces well.

name: Silver Iris
manufacturer_description: Is a beautiful dark purple with lots of silver that is not affected by strong oxidizing / reduction flame. Get lovely blue/purple haze with annealing. The color intensity increases in larger work with more vivid colors. A popular color combo is Silver Iris and Magic Mirror.

name: Purple Thunder
manufacturer_description: This is a strong striking purple; very easy to strike. Beautiful pinks, rose, blue, creams and purples. Use an oxidizing flame. Best results are with some flame striking.

name: Violet Medley
manufacturer_description: An artist's favorite striking color. The rod is a funky avocado green and is worked like any amber purple by heating to white hot and keeping the surface haze burned off. When the piece is finished let it cool till the orange glow is gone and then strike to purples by reintroducing the piece to the outermost portion of the flame. Areas that have had the haze burned off will turn a rich dark transparent purple and areas that the haze is left on show up as a pretty cloudy blue. It is very easy to flame strike.

name: Apache
manufacturer_description: This multi-color glass is a whirl-wind of yellows, reds and oranges all separated by a bit of black. The colors are rich and intense. Easy to work and just screams out: wig-wag.

name: Challenge Cherry Blossom
manufacturer_description: Challenge series color with pinks, reds, ambers and white can strike to deeper reds; very versatile and easy to use.

name: Gypsy Queen
manufacturer_description: This multi-color glass reds, blues, greens, and white colors. This smooth and easy to work colorful rod offers new design options. Use cool flame if you want to keep the vivid colors.

name: Matador
manufacturer_description: This multi-color glass has two stripes of dark black, two stripes of red with thin separations of creamy white color. This bold color is easy to work and does best in a neutral flame; great in all applications.

name: Marlee
manufacturer_description: This multi-color is a classic. Red, Yellow and Green, all separated by Obsidian.

name: Amethyst Ice
manufacturer_description: This multi-color glass consists of two bands of plum harvest and two bands of a cream/white color. This color creates very unique effects in sculptural work; is great for quick canes for coil-pots and inside-out work. This rod makes detail very easy.

name: Rhapsody in Blue
manufacturer_description: This multi-color rod contains a symphony of cool hues of blues, emeralds and teals that dance and swirl through the rod. This glass works well inside and out, encased or not and makes a great twistie.

name: Infinity III -
manufacturer_description: This multi-color glass of vibrant blue and bright yellow is stable in deep encasements, and the yellow appears more lemony. Twisties can be pulled thin and the pattern remains clear. This glass works easily in all applications.

name: Marlee II
manufacturer_description: Multi-color rod of classic colors – red, gold and green separated by obsidian. Each of the colors is covered with clear to prevent cracking. Use a cool flame if you want to keep these vivid colors.

name: Infinity II (Coral Snake)
manufacturer_description: This multi-color glass has eight bands separated by clear. This one we playfully call coral snake. It is a yellow-dark blue-reddish combination that is easy to use and twists well.

name: Infinity
manufacturer_description: This multi-color glass has eight distinct bands of blues, reds, green and striking colors separated by clear. Easy to use, and makes a great twisty.

name: Moonlight Sonata
manufacturer_description: This multi-color rod has wonderful hues of blues, reds, whites and greens with a wispy pearly stripe. This glass works great in all applications. Moonlight Sonata makes a fast and beautiful cane when twisted.

name: Black Rose
manufacturer_description: An intense black with a dark rose violet undertone. Surface can get a little grey in heavy reducing atmosphere; recommend neutral to oxidizing flame. Black Rose is stable, durable and smooth. Thinning can result in transparent color.

name: Obsidian
manufacturer_description: A strong dark cobalt blue that does not thin out. Avoid reducing flame. Neutral flame works best.

name: Black Bird
manufacturer_description: Black rod with beautiful rich black tone. No reducing problems as long as you work is on an oxygen-rich flame. Stays bright and dense when worked in a deep encasement. It is non-transparent, non-reflective, our darkest and least transparent black. It is a darker black than our other black, Black Rose.

name: 10 inch labeled sample - multi color only; 40+ colors
10 inch labeled sample -solid color only; 40+ colors
Clear
manufacturer_description: Clear RainWater is a satiny, clear, glass with crystal droplets embedded throughout the sheet. May require a bubble-squeeze for use in fusing. name: Sea Green
manufacturer_description: Sea Green Artique is a cool-leaning, pale green transparent glass with subtle light refraction. Also available in other sheet textures and accessory products. May require a bubble-squeeze for use in fusing. name: Licorice Swirl
manufacturer_description: Licorice Swirl OpalArt Fusible offers our deepest black swirled onto a bed of pristine white opal for the ultimate bold contrast in a glass palette. name: Light Purple
manufacturer_description: Light Purple Waterglass offers a light, warm-leaning purple transparent with subtle movement. Also available in other sheet textures and accessory products. May require a bubble-squeeze for use in fusing. name: Pale Purple
manufacturer_description: Pale Purple Waterglass is a lovely blushing rosé transparent with subtle movement. Also available in other sheet textures, Frit, Noodles, and Stringers. May require a bubble-squeeze for use in fusing. Details & Specs Opacity: Transparent Process: Continuous Ribbon Texture: Textured Thickness: Standard (3mm) Variegation: Single Color Usage: Fusible Sheet Sizes Full Sheet: 48 in x 22 in Half Sheet: 24 in x 22 in Hobby Sheet: 12 in x 12 in

name: Pale Blue Rough Rolled
manufacturer_description: Pale Blue Rough Rolled offers a pale, icy transparent with textural interest. Also available in other sheet textures, Rods, and Frit. May require a bubble-squeeze for use in fusing. Details & Specs Opacity: Transparent Process: Continuous Ribbon Texture: Textured Thickness: Standard (3mm) Variegation: Single Color Usage: Fusible Sheet Sizes Full Sheet: 48 in x 24 in Half Sheet: 24 in x 24 in Hobby Sheet: 12 in x 12 in

name: Pale Amber Rough Rolled
manufacturer_description: Transparent Pale Amber Rough Rolled offers subtle warmth and an interesting texture to your work. Available in several other textures and glass accessory products. Details & Specs Opacity: Transparent Process: Continuous Ribbon Texture: Textured Thickness: Standard (3mm) Variegation: Single Color Usage: Fusible Sheet Sizes Full Sheet: 48 in x 24 in Half Sheet: 24 in x 24 in Hobby Sheet: 12 in x 12 in

name: Clear Krinkle
manufacturer_description: Clear Krinkle offers a glass that is seemingly folded and creased, fracturing backgrounds into slices of color and light. May require a bubble-squeeze for use in fusing. Details & Specs Opacity: Transparent Process: Continuous Ribbon Texture: Textured Thickness: Standard (3mm) Variegation: Single Color Usage: Fusible Sheet Sizes Full Sheet: 48 in x 24 in Half Sheet: 24 in x 24 in Hobby Sheet: 12 in x 12 in

name: Dark Purple/White, Wispy
manufacturer_description: Dark Purple/White, Wispy Smooth Fusible is a deep burgundy wine translucent glass with subtle wisps of opal stirred throughout the sheet. Details & Specs Opacity: Translucent Process: Continuous Ribbon Texture: Smooth Thickness: Standard (3mm) Variegation: Color-mix Usage: Fusible Sheet Sizes Full Sheet: 48 in x 24 in Half Sheet: 24 in x 24 in Hobby Sheet: 12 in x 12 in

name: Dark Purple
manufacturer_description: Dark Purple Waterglass is a deep, rich, burgundy wine color with the subtle movement of the Waterglass texture. May require a bubble-squeeze for use in fusing. May require a bubble-squeeze for use in fusing. Details & Specs Opacity: Transparent Process: Continuous Ribbon Texture: Textured Thickness: Standard (3mm) Variegation: Single Color Usage: Fusible Sheet Sizes Full Sheet: 48 in x 22 in Half Sheet: 24 in x 22 in Hobby Sheet: 12 in x 12 in Fusible Accessories Stringers Noodles

name: Blackberry Cream
manufacturer_description: Blackberry Cream OpalArt Fusible offers hypnotic swirls of cool, purplish blues on a crystal opal base. Details & Specs Opacity: Opalescent Process: Continuous Ribbon Texture: Smooth Thickness: Standard (3mm) Variegation: Color-mix Usage: Fusible Sheet Sizes Full Sheet: 48 in x 24 in Half Sheet: 24 in x 24 in Hobby Sheet: 12 in x 12 in

name: Solid White Opal Double-Thick 5MM
manufacturer_description: Solid White Opal Thin 2MM Fusible is our pristine white solid opalescent glass offered in a thin option for delicate layering and jewelry-making. Details & Specs Opacity: Opalescent Process: Continuous Ribbon Texture: Smooth Thickness: Thin (2mm) Variegation: Single Color Usage: Fusible Sheet Sizes Full Sheet: 48 in x 24 in Half Sheet: 24 in x 24 in Hobby Sheet: 12 in x 12 in

name: Aquamarine Transparent
manufacturer_description: Aquamarine is a medium-range blue-green — a lovely, bright hue landing a stair-step above Sea Green and Caribbean in the color group. Details & Specs Opacity: Transparent Process: Continuous Ribbon Texture: Smooth Thickness: Standard (3mm) Variegation: Single Color Usage: Fusible Sheet Sizes Full Sheet: 48 in x 24 in Half Sheet: 24 in x 24 in Hobby Sheet: 12 in x 12 in

name: Red Elvis
manufacturer_description: Red Elvis is an “easy striker” and self strikes as it cools but gets a little darker with flame striking or kiln striking. Red Elvis strikes in an oxidizing atmosphere, at a slightly lower temperature than most rubies. Work in a neutral to oxidizing flame. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Dark Red Elvis
manufacturer_description: Dark Red Elvis is very saturated, and is a great choice for a red in thin stringers and thin blown work. Dark Red Elvis self strikes as it cools but gets a little bit darker with kiln striking, or flame striking. It will flame strike in a neutral to oxidizing atmosphere, at a slightly lower temperature than most rubies. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Light Red Elvis
manufacturer_description: Light Red Elvis strikes in an oxidizing atmosphere, at a slightly lower temperature than most rubies. Work in a neutral to oxidizing flame. A lighter and more transparent shade of our popular self-striking red. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Yellow Elvis
manufacturer_description: Yellow Elvis is a lightly reactive amber/purple type color- an easy striking yellow that will self-strike as it cools but darkens with kiln striking, or with flame striking in an oxy environment. Oxidizing flame brings out brighter tones, reduction gives softer earthier colors. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Black Jack
manufacturer_description: Black Jack goes almost clear when hot, but self-strikes back through brown to near-black depending on how thick you use it. BlackJack likes an oxidizing flame, but does not reduce with gray streaks like most black boro colors. In the curls shown here, we had to get the glass right on top of the light to see the brown where it’s thinner. Black Jack is not suitable for thin stringer work where you want the stringers to look like a dense black, but it’s the perfect color for very specific things, like sculpting without the graying. This is the only color i like for backing my squiggle, nothing like it This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Apricot
manufacturer_description: Apricot is a lightly reactive amber/purple type color, a little darker than Yellow Elvis. Apricot self-strikes, and gains some blue or purple highlights. Oxy flames bring out brighter tones, reduction gives softer earthier colors. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: TurboCo
manufacturer_description: TurboCo is a highly saturated cobalt blue. Use thick as a substitute for black, or thinner as a dark blue. Work TurboCo in an oxidizing atmosphere; reducing may cause gray streaks. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Caramelo
manufacturer_description: Caramelo is a very saturated and reactive opaque amber/purple type glass. Rods are fairly opaque. Oxidize to strike up brighter colors; reduce for flesh and earth tones. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: SlyRm
manufacturer_description: This glass keeps the bright, highlighter-green of our Slyme, and stays transparent! What you see is what you get with this color -there is no milk strike. It is easy working and adds pop to whatever you put it on! This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Slyme
manufacturer_description: Ah, Slyme. Ectoplasmic! One of the most unusual colors in the boro palette, Slyme can range from transparent to translucent to a milky semi-opaque, depending on how you work it. Work cooler to keep Slyme more opaque, with a soft reducing flame. Goes transparent under higher heat, but can develop a ghostly milky green haze. Wonderful color. Always silky-smooth and a pleasure to work. As the description says – apply / warm up this color in a reducing environment. But, as per a Trautman instructional video on this color, you can use an oxidizing flame once you’ve warmed it up in a reducing flame first. Just be sure you do it in the right order, otherwise you’ll mess with the color. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Blue Blizzard
manufacturer_description: Blue Blizzard is transparent to semi-opaque cobalt shot through with flecks of white glass “snow” that we make especially for the Blizzard colors. The white bits remain distinct, even after working the piece, and rough rods smooth out nicely in the flame. Should be worked in a neutral or oxidizing atmosphere to prevent graying. Blue Blizzard most resembles the stone Lapis Lazuli or old-fashioned speckled enamel-on-metal camping dishes. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Red Blizzard
manufacturer_description: Red Blizzard is a transparent to semi-opaque red glass shot through with flecks of white glass “snow.” Rough rods that smooth out in the flame. Red Blizzard should be worked in a neutral or oxidizing atmosphere to keep the white bits from boiling but its a pretty flame tolerant glass. The “snow” of the Blizzard line resembles stone or old-fashioned speckled enamel-on-metal dishes. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Pink Cadillac
manufacturer_description: Pink Cadillac is a opaque and dense pink that prefers a soft, enveloping flame. While it is not really boily, they do have some air in them which can mimic boil, especially when heated hard and fast. For those of you on sharp and forceful torches in particular we suggest warming in the upper flame before working slowly and allowing the occasional larger air bubbles to escape as you work. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Penumbra
manufacturer_description: Named for the shadowy edge of a lunar eclipse, Penumbra is a reactive “silvered” cobalt blue. Different colors are produced from reduction or oxidation, primarily a wide variety of blues and greens. Reduction can create a luster that you can trap under a clear encasement. However, surface haze doesn’t burn off as easily as amber/purple type glasses. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Queen Bee
manufacturer_description: Queen Bee is the less saturated cousin of Caramelo. Easy to strike. She allows more light to penetrate the finished work, which shows more purples and pinks. Oxidize to strike up brighter colors; reduce for fleshy and earthy tones. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Wisteria
manufacturer_description: Wisteria was a breakthrough color for the boro palette: a dense opaque purple that is only translucent when thin. Textured rods smooth out in the flame. Like all of the opaque Candy colors, Wisteria prefers a soft, enveloping flame. Its not boily, but it can have some air in the rods. If you put it into an forceful flame when cold, the air rushing to the surface can mimic boil. This is why we suggest working slowly and in a bushy soft neutral flame, to allow the occasional larger air bubbles to escape as you work. While many people have great success with these colors, the opaque Candy color line is known to have a slightly higher COE; please test in your application. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Stag White
manufacturer_description: Stag is a very dense, bright opaque white that retains its opacity even when fairly thin. However, it will show texture when honeycombed or in thin stringers in a marble. (For a smoother dense white, choose TAG-033-33 Whiteout.) Stag works up smooth despite graininess in the rod although it can retain a visual texture, and it resists boiling once brought to temp and kept hot. Stag works fine in all flame atmospheres; however, a cooler flame is suggested for all boro whites. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Purple Sable
manufacturer_description: Purple Sable is a very unusual amber/purple with a coffee-colored base and a light aventurine sparkle. The best reactions occur in a mid-range of temperatures, not too hot or too cool. Purple Sable shows different effects in different flame atmospheres – reduction, oxidation, and encasement. For a nice opalescence, trap the reduction effects under a layer of clear. Blues, purples, greens, ambers, and more can be produced on the surface of this glass. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Heavy Blue Leprechaun
manufacturer_description: Heavy Blue Leprechaun uses a more stable aventurine technology produces very densely saturated aventurines with large, dichro-like sparkles. Not sensitive to flame atmosphere, but reduction should be avoided on any aventurines before implosion. Please limit long, hot garaging. This is also a good choice for mixing down with other colors to add rainbow sparkles, although it will leave traces of blue. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Blue Stardust
manufacturer_description: This is a transparent aventurine sapphire blue with big, glittery dichro-like sparkles. Great for layering. The usual cautions against long, hot garaging technically apply since this is an aventurine color, however it is stable in implosions, encasements, and virtually any application. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Heavy Blue Stardust
manufacturer_description: Transparent darker blue aventurine with big, glittery dichro-like sparkles. Great for layering or backing, also mixes down with other colors to add sparkle. Heavy Blue Stardust is darker blue sapphire with a higher density of sparkle, than the regular Blue Stardust. The usual cautions against long, hot garaging technically apply since this is an aventurine color, however it is stable in implosions and encasements. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Whiteout
manufacturer_description: Whiteout is a very smooth and creamy white and resists boil once it is brought up to temperature in a cool flame. Smooth texture which makes it better suited to working thin in marbles or in honeycombs. Not sensitive to atmosphere but use a cool soft flame to start out. best white out there, very dense and great for stringers. I really wish they’d make it again… Much more dense and a more true white than star white. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Dwarf White
manufacturer_description: Very smooth and creamy. Dwarf White is a bit translucent, and is perfect for those times when you don’t want much density – if you are making clouds or teeth, for example. Resists boil once brought up to temperature in the softer upper flame. Dwarf has a fine, smooth texture and is not sensitive to atmosphere, but many people like to use a lot of oxy with white boro to reduce the chance of boil. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Knight Rider
manufacturer_description: Knight Rider is a smooth dark black. You can pull it quite thin and still have a good, solid black stringer. Like most standard black boro glasses, Knight Rider is a dense black that likes an oxy environment, and can gray out a little with reduction. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Mai Tai Pink
manufacturer_description: Mai Tai Pink is colorless in the rod, but it changes dramatically in the kiln after being flame worked! Flame strikes to barely amber yellow, but it’s designed to change considerably during longer annealing at 1050. May be kilned repeatedly for more color, or ramped up to 1150 to speed the strike. Can also be un-struck in the flame after the kiln cycle for interesting color-fade effects. It is virtually impossible to over-strike this color. Burn off haze for more pinks or leave the haze for more purple effects. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Double Mai Tai
manufacturer_description: Double Mai Tai is a member of the amber/purple family, but with less amber and more pinks and purples. It can gain more color in the kiln, but it strikes well in the flame, with lots of pink — especially over a base of white. Double Mai Tai is hard to over-strike. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Mega Mai Tai
manufacturer_description: Unlike the Mai Tai Pink, Mega Mai Tai gives massive color in the flame, not the kiln. It also tends more toward purple and blue than pink. Strikes and reduces. It is a member of the amber/purple family, which tend to feature less amber and more pinks and purples. May also be kiln struck if you prefer. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Mighty Moss
manufacturer_description: Mighty Moss features newer aventurine technology, which has greatly improved the stability of glitter boro colors. This glass is a very densely saturated aventurine with large, dichro-like sparkles. Limit the time you “garage” your work, do not go above 1050 in the anneal cycle, and anneal as short a time as you can for the size of the piece. Not sensitive to flame atmosphere, but reduction should be avoided on aventurines before implosion. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Sasha’s Oil Slick
manufacturer_description: A dark member of the amber/purple family, This color is dense but transparent, and most often produces olive greens and soft browns. However, with a softer flame you can strike color ON the silver haze, particularly ambers, oranges, and blues. Oil Slick can also be worked in a very hot, high oxygen flame for more purples, blues and pastels. Sasha also sometimes kiln-strikes this color for more variations in shade, or quick-cools it between strikes. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Green Stardust
manufacturer_description: Transparent light green aventurine with big, glittery dichro-like sparkles. Great for layering sparkle over other colors, like amber/purples, without adding much hue. Green Stardust is a light leaf shade. The usual cautions against long, hot garaging technically apply since this is an aventurine color, however it is stable in implosions. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Green X
manufacturer_description: Blue in the rod, Green X will come out of the kiln a dark, dense green. Green X is reactive and can strike with a milky bluish bloom. This bloom can be trapped under encasement. Not atmosphere dependent. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Green XLT
manufacturer_description: Another one that is blue in the rod, but kiln strikes to a dark, dense green. Green XLt is lighter than Green X and does not bloom – it’s a reliable dollar-bill green once kiln struck. Not atmosphere dependent. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Heavy Xxenon
manufacturer_description: Satiny shimmering sparkler that shifts greener in the kiln. Heavy XXenon is quite opaque with big, glittery dichro-like sparkles. Heavy Xxenon can bloom with a light blue haze, especially where encased, like our Green X. The usual cautions for an aventurine color apply: limit long hot garaging and encase with care. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Sparky
manufacturer_description: Sparky is fairly opaque and is made up of silver sparkles. You can work it from the rod without re-mixing, or you can mix it down with any color to add bling. Sparky has proven to be stable and implodable. Rough textured rods smooth out beautifully in the flame. Great for layering. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Champagne
manufacturer_description: Champagne Sparky is a smooth champagne rod with silvery sparkles, and may be worked from the rod without re-mixing. Great for layering when used thinner as it adds nice sparkle. Champagne will strike a tad bit darker in the kiln, an effect that is particularly noticeable when it’s used thicker. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Orange Elvis
manufacturer_description: Just as the name implies, Orange Elvis is a mix of the self-striking Red Elvis and the lightly reactive amber/purple type Yellow Elvis. This makes it an easy-strike color that will flame strike a lighter reddish orange, or can be brought back to clear in the flame and then kiln strike for a darker reddish-orange look. Layer over clear to make a more true transparent orange. Oxy flames bring out brighter tones, reduction gives softer earthier colors due to the a/p component. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Honey Badger
manufacturer_description: TAG’s Honey Badger is a nice, non-reactive transparent amber, perfect for honey bee themes. What You See Is What You Get kind of color. Not atmosphere dependent but prefers to be worked in a cooler, softer flame. The high concentration of colorants in this glass can promote boiling if you work it too hot and too fast. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Darth Badger
manufacturer_description: The Darth Badger is a non-reactive reddish amber on “the dark side.” A darker, more saturated version of the Honey Badger, the Darth is very nice in applications where you want to use an amber very thin and still show amber, or where you just want a darker and richer shade. It is highly saturated with colorants, however, and will boil if heated too fast. Non-reactive and works in any atmosphere, but prefers to be worked higher up in a bushy soft flame. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Pink Slyme
manufacturer_description: Pink Slyme strikes milky to semi-opaque depending on how you work it. Pink Slyme does not need as much reduction as our other Slymes, and is a pink-purple with the same density and milk-strike as a regular green Slyme. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Shooting Star
manufacturer_description: Shooting Star is a mix of Blue Stardust aventurine with reactive silver. It is the lightest of the silver reactive stardust based colors. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: IO Star
manufacturer_description: IO Star is a mix of Blue Stardust aventurine with reactive silver. Io Star is medium saturation with a greener base This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Europa Star
manufacturer_description: Europa Star is a mix of Heavy Blue Stardust aventurine with reactive silver. This is the most dense out of the striking stardust formulas with both silver reactivity and sparkle saturation. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Fade to Black
manufacturer_description: Fade to Black is a unique striking color that has the ability to flow through shades of black, blue, green, and white as the glass is flame struck. This is a refined version of our earlier experimental batches, and this recipe is the most colorful, stable and compatible yet. If you’re looking for a tricky color – this is probably the trickiest I’m continuing to learn to date. There’s some resources online, but to bring them here: As it’s worked, it strikes from black to blue to white. If you lay on dots of clear / color over this color, it will seek towards that strike rapidly. This makes it not too ideal for encasement, so proceed with caution on that front. If you love NS-127 I’d say play with this color. Just don’t invest yourself into your first couple/few pieces with it until you learn how it plays. This color’s a whole different beast in terms of its striking nature. I use in my solid work, pendants mostly. You don’t have to do much of anything to get the range of colors. Customers are very attracted to the color. If used on a blown piece I never melt it totally in. I haven’t found the mix of gas to matter. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Pink Lollipop
manufacturer_description: This is the transparent version of the hugely popular Pink Cadillac. Transparent vibrant pink with micro air bubbles throughout the rods. Flame stable and easy to use! This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Purple Lollipop
manufacturer_description: This is the transparent version of the hugely popular Wisteria. Transparent vibrant purple with micro air bubbles throughout the rods. Flame stable and easy to use! This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Sea Slyme
manufacturer_description: Sea Slyme is a variation on our popular Slyme green: it ranges from transparent where thin or heated more, to translucent with a milky strike where it’s worked cooler. But instead of an ectoplasmic green, this glass is a beautiful sea foam light blue-green. Like other Slyme colors, this glass likes a soft flame, especially when starting cold. We prefer a bushy soft neutral to slightly reducing flame with this color. Generally speaking, if you get scuzz on the surface, turn down the oxygen and go a bit slower. If you are getting any graying, turn down the gas a little. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Blue Slyme
manufacturer_description: Blue Slyme is a variation on our popular Slyme green: it ranges from transparent where thin or heated more, to translucent with a milky strike where it’s worked cooler. But instead of an ectoplasmic green, this glass is a beautiful light-to-medium blue. Like other Slymes, this glass likes a soft flame, especially when starting cold. We prefer a bushy soft neutral flame with this color. Generally speaking, if you get scuzz on the surface, turn down the oxygen and go a bit slower. If you are getting any graying, turn down the gas a little. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Dark Blue Slyme
manufacturer_description: Dark Blue Slyme has everything you know and love about a Slyme: finished work can range from opaque to translucent to transparent in the same piece from the same rod of color. You can bring out a milky strike that gives visual depth, and you can pull out rich color where the strike is burned away. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Blu-V
manufacturer_description: Blu-V is a clear glass that fluoresces blue under a U.V. light source. Recommend to use an ultraviolet L.E.D. light with a 365Nm-395Nm range for the brightest blue glow. This is a stable glass and can be used in any type of flame. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Pink Proton (UV reactive)
manufacturer_description: Pink Proton is clear glass with minimal air, and when worked it remains quite clear in normal lighting. Under UV lighting it is a very intense hot pink! A very stable color to add to the UV pallet. Pink Proton works great on the surface and can also be worked under clear. Fantastic for blown and sculpted applications. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Syzygy (CFL Reactive)
manufacturer_description: Syzygy is a florescent light reactive glass that is a light golden yellow under sunlight and most artificial light, and shifts to a vibrant transparent pink under florescent light. Syzygy, pronounced “siz-i-jee”, is an astronomical term for the alignment of three celestial bodies https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Syzygy . It is an easy to use color and is not reactive to flame’s atmosphere. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Atomic Stardust (UV reactive)
manufacturer_description: This is an eye-catching mix of our Blue Stardust and Blu-V recipes. This glass takes a light blue shade and aventurine sparkle from TAG Blue Stardust, and takes a strong blue UV reaction from Blu-V. The result is a beautiful UV reactive color that looks amazing in all types of light. When hit with a UV light, this color has a deep blue glow that pairs very nicely with Pink Proton. Atomic Stardust is a highly stable, smooth working color, and likes an oxidized to neutral flame. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Tropical Green
manufacturer_description: Tropical Green is a rich, transparent green reminiscent of jungle palms and warm southern waves. Depending on how it is worked, this green will also develop turquoise Slyme-like highlights to deliver the full tropical effect! This color is a transparent version of Sea Slyme, and in thicker applications, near reheated areas, and when the color is used under clear, a subtle blue milk strike will appear. In thinner and hotter applications this color will stay transparent and green. Tropical Green is a very smooth working color that bends, pulls, and coils easily. The color is also stable in all flame environments, and will retain its clarity after it is worked. Tropical green is a dynamic color that you can use as a pure transparent green, or bring out its shades of blue to add another dimension in your work. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Parallax - CFL Reactive
manufacturer_description: Parallax is a stunning magenta-purple with a powerful color shift. Under natural and non fluorescent light Parallax is a smokey grey, but transitions to bright fuchsia when brought under a fluorescent light source. Unlike some other fluorescent light reactive colors out there, this shift is obvious and brilliant! Parallax is an easy working color that is not reactive to flame atmosphere- artists enjoy how this color behaves is the flame! This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Sunset Slyme (CFL Reactive)
manufacturer_description: The first CFL Slyme we have mixed up! Under non fluorescent light you will get a smooth slyme -green, and the color will shift to a rosey sienna when hit with a fluorescent bulb! As with other slymes , this color will stay milky and opaque where worked cool, and become more transparent where worked hot. The normal working tips for slyme apply to sunset slyme . This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Light Blue Stardust
manufacturer_description: This is a light transparent aventurine sapphire blue, glittery dichro-like sparkles. About half the saturation as standard Blue Stardust. Great for layering on top of other colors. Easy to use and flame stable color. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Phaze (CFL Reactive)
manufacturer_description: A bright, CFL reactive magenta. This shifting color that falls in-between the purple of Parallax and the pink of Syzygy. Under Fluorescent light this color reflects a bright magenta, and in natural or non-fluorescent light it will shift to a light, almost clear champagne. A smooth working and flame tolerant color that likes a neutral flame environment. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.

name: Secret White
manufacturer_description: This is a translucent white with an opalescent sheen and a slight milky heat strike. Easy to use color in any flame environment. Air content is minimal, but still contain micro air bubbles. This field is for validation purposes and should be left unchanged.
